After arriving, he headed to the [[Imperial Hotel, Tokyo|Imperial Hotel]] to meet with Japanese businessmen,<ref name="Japanese business meeting">{{cite news|last1=Calonzo|first1=Andreo|title=PNoy tells Japanese traders now's the best time to invest in PHL|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/498358/economy/business/pnoy-tells-japanese-traders-now-s-the-best-time-to-invest-in-phl|accessdate=June 4, 2015|publisher=[[GMA News and Public Affairs]]|date=June 4, 2015}}</ref> before meeting with the [[Filipinos in Japan|Filipino community]] at [[Okura Hotels|Hotel Okura]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Speech: President Aquino meets with the Filipino community in Tokyo, Japan|url=http://www.gov.ph/2015/06/03/speech-president-aquino-filipino-community-tokyo-japan/|publisher=''[[Official Gazette (Philippines)|Official Gazette]]''|accessdate=June 3, 2015|date=June 3, 2015}}</ref>
On Wednesday, June 3, President Aquino was received by [[Emperor of Japan|Emperor]] [[Akihito]] and [[Empress of Japan|Empress]] [[Michiko]] at the [[Tokyo Imperial Palace|Imperial Palace]]. During their meeting, President Aquino was awarded the Grand Cordon of the [[Order of the Chrysanthemum]] by Emperor Akihito, who in return was awarded the Grand Collar (''Supremo'') of the [[Order of Lakandula]] by President Aquino for bolstering the [[Japan–Philippines relations]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Quismundo|first1=Tarra|title=Aquino gets Japan's highest honor from imperial family|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/123907/aquino-gets-japans-highest-honor-from-imperial-family|accessdate=June 3, 2015|publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=June 3, 2015|location=Tokyo}}</ref> President Aquino also attended the 21st International Conference on The Future of Asia organized by [[Nikkei 225]] at Hotel Okura, where he delivered a keynote speech. During his keynote speech, President Aquino urged China to reconsider [[Land reclamations of the People's Republic of China|their land reclamation activities]] in the West Philippine Sea, as it breaches the conditions of the 2002 ASEAN–China Declaration on the Conduct of Parties, comparing China's actions to [[Nazi Germany]]'s [[Nazi Germany#Geography|territorial expansion]] before [[World War II]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Willard|title=Aquino to China: Rethink reclamation|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/06/03/15/aquino-china-rethink-reclamation|accessdate=June 3, 2015|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs]]|date=June 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Takenaka|first1=Kiyoshi|title=Aquino compares China and Nazi Germany anew|url=http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2015/06/03/Aquino-compares-China-and-Nazi-Germany-anew.html|accessdate=June 8, 2015|agency=[[Reuters]]|publisher=[[CNN Philippines]]|date=June 3, 2015}}</ref> Later that afternoon, President Aquino addressed a joint session of the [[National Diet]], seeking Japan's assistance to resolve the territorial disputes.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bacani|first1=Louis|title=Aquino slams China in speech before Japanese parliament|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/06/03/1461819/aquino-slams-china-speech-japanese-parliament|accessdate=June 3, 2015|publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]''|date=June 3, 2015}}</ref> In the evening, Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko hosted a [[state dinner]] for President Aquino at the Imperial Palace.<ref>{{cite web|title=Toast of President Aquino for the state banquet hosted by the Emperor and Empress of Japan, June 3, 2015|url=http://www.gov.ph/2015/06/03/toast-president-aquino-state-banquet-japan-emperor-empress/|publisher=''[[Official Gazette (Philippines)|Official Gazette]]''|accessdate=June 3, 2015|date=June 3, 2015}}</ref>
On Thursday, June 4, President Aquino attended the Philippine Investment Forum at the [[Hotel New Otani Tokyo|Hotel New Otani]], attended by over 1,000 Japanese businessmen, urging them to invest in information technology, infrastructure, and manufacturing in the Philippines.<ref name="Japanese business meeting"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Willard|title=Aquino: Philippines a 'far cry' from 5 years ago|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/business/06/04/15/pnoy-woos-japanese-investors-tokyo-forum|accessdate=June 4, 2015|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs]]|date=June 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Porcalla|first1=Delon|title=Invest in Phl now, Noy urges traders|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/06/05/1462359/invest-phl-now-noy-urges-traders|accessdate=June 8, 2015|publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]''|date=June 5, 2015}}</ref> He then headed to the [[Akasaka Palace]] to meet with Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] for a bilateral meeting, followed by a joint press conference and an official dinner in the evening.<ref name="Noy to visit Canada, Japan"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Toast of President Aquino at a dinner hosted by the Prime Minister of Japan|url=http://www.gov.ph/2015/06/05/toast-of-president-aquino-at-a-dinner-hosted-by-the-prime-minister-of-japan/|publisher=''[[Official Gazette (Philippines)|Official Gazette]]''|accessdate=June 8, 2015|date=June 4, 2015}}</ref> The two heads of government discussed the enhancement of the [[strategic partnership]] between Japan and the Philippines, as well as developments over the territorial disputes in the South China Sea. President Aquino also thanked Prime Minister Abe for Japan's efforts in aiding the victims of [[Typhoon Haiyan|Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda)]] and their support towards the [[Bangsamoro (political entity)|Bangsamoro]] [[Peace process with the Bangsamoro in the Philippines|peace process]].<ref name="Japan 2015"/> They then witnessed the signing of the Memorandum of Cooperation for Healthcare, signed by the [[Department of Health (Philippines)|Philippine Department of Health]] and the [[Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare|Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare]] to further enhance [[universal health care]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Statement of President Aquino during the summit meeting with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe|url=http://www.gov.ph/2015/06/04/statement-president-aquino-summit-meeting-shinzo-abe/|publisher=''[[Official Gazette (Philippines)|Official Gazette]]''|accessdate=June 4, 2015|date=June 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Quismundo|first1=Tarra|title=Sea row tops agenda of Aquino visit to Japan|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/123708/sea-row-tops-agenda-of-aquino-visit-to-japan|accessdate=June 4, 2015|publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=May 30, 2015}}</ref>
On Friday, June 5, President Aquino held a joint press conference with the [[Japan National Press Club]], where he announced his intentions for a [[Visiting Forces Agreement]] with Japan in order for Japanese troops to assist in defense over the territorial disputes in the South China Sea.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yamaguchi|first1=Mari|title=Philippines wants defense pact for Japanese troops|url=https://news.yahoo.com/philippines-eyes-defense-pact-japanese-troop-visits-064444772.html|accessdate=June 8, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Yahoo! News]]|date=June 5, 2015}}</ref> He was also met by Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko at the Imperial Hotel,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Quismundo|first1=Tarra|title=Aquino: No to Cha-cha, term extension|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/696421/aquino-no-to-cha-cha-term-extension|accessdate=June 8, 2015|publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=June 5, 2015}}</ref> before heading to Haneda Airport to depart Tokyo for Manila with ₱13.5 billion investment pledges from eleven companies and ₱136.9 billion of concessional loans for infrastructure projects.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fabunan|first1=Sara Susanne D.|title=Aquino brings home P150B in Japanese aid|url=http://manilastandardtoday.com/2015/06/07/aquino-brings-home-p150b-in-japanese-aid/|accessdate=June 8, 2015|publisher=''[[The New Standard (Philippine newspaper)|Manila Standard Today]]''|date=June 7, 2015}}</ref>
===Malaysia (November 20–22)=== President Aquino attended the 27th [[ASEAN Summit]] and the [[Tenth East Asia Summit|Tenth]] [[East Asia Summit]] in Kuala Lumpur, his last before [[Philippine presidential election, 2016|stepping down from office]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cruz|first1=RG|title=PNoy says goodbye to ASEAN leaders|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/focus/11/22/15/pnoy-says-goodbye-to-asean-leaders|accessdate=November 23, 2015|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|date=November 22, 2015}}</ref> During the ASEAN Summit, President Aquino and the other ASEAN leaders announced the creation of the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations#ASEAN Economic Community Blueprint|ASEAN Economic Community]], an economic integration between ASEAN member states to begin on December 31, 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Leaders create ASEAN Economic Community, but challenges remain|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/leaders-create-asean-economic-community-but-challenges-remain/|accessdate=November 22, 2015|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=November 22, 2015}}</ref> After the summit, the ASEAN leaders signed the ASEAN Convention on Trafficking in Persons (ACTIP) to address the issue of [[human trafficking]], especially within women and children.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cruz|first1=RG|title=ASEAN signs convention vs human trafficking|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/global-filipino/11/21/15/asean-signs-convention-vs-human-trafficking|accessdate=November 23, 2015|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|date=November 21, 2015}}</ref>
===France, Italy, and Vatican City (November 29–December 4)=== [[File:Benigno Aquino III and Pope Francis 12.4.15.jpg|thumb|President Aquino meeting with Pope Francis for the former's [[papal audience]] at Vatican City, December 4, 2015]] During an interview at the [[APEC Philippines 2015#CEO Summit|APEC CEO Summit]] on November 16, President Aquino announced his participation in the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] in Paris, amidst the [[November 2015 Paris attacks#Aftermath|aftermath of the recent Paris attacks]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Porcalla|first1=Delon|title=Noy going to Paris for climate summit|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2015/11/17/1522806/noy-going-paris-climate-summit|accessdate=November 22, 2015|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=November 17, 2015}}</ref> On November 26, [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Philippines)|Department of Foreign Affairs]] Assistant Secretary Maria Cleofe Natividad announced that President Aquino would also undertake a working visit to Rome, where he would meet with Italian President [[Sergio Mattarella]] and Italian Prime Minister [[Matteo Renzi]] and have an audience with [[Pope Francis]] in Vatican City to reciprocate [[Pope Francis's visit to the Philippines|the pope's visit to the Philippines the previous January]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Aquino to meet Pope Francis in Vatican after attending COP21 in Paris|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/aquino-to-meet-pope-francis-in-vatican-after-attending-cop21-in-paris/|accessdate=November 26, 2015|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]|agency=[[Philippines News Agency]]|date=November 26, 2015}}</ref> At the Climate Change Conference in Paris, President Aquino delivered a three-minute speech "that highlights Philippine response to the impact of [[climate change]] and campaign for the inclusion of human rights, the vulnerability of indigenous peoples and gender issues in the Paris agreement."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dizon|first1=Nikko|title=Aquino to deliver 3-minute speech at Paris summit|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/132890/aquino-to-deliver-3-minute-speech-at-paris-summit|accessdate=November 28, 2015|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=November 27, 2015}}</ref>
President Aquino arrived at the [[Paris–Le Bourget Airport]] on Sunday, November 29, at around 6:15 pm [[Central European Time|CET]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Arrival in Paris, France|url=http://rtvm.gov.ph/main/?tag=arrival-in-paris|publisher=[[Presidential Communications Group (Philippines)|Presidential Communications Operations Office]]|accessdate=November 30, 2015|date=November 29, 2015}}</ref>
==2016== In 2016, President Aquino made his last official visit.
===United States (February 15–17)=== [[File:Benigno Aquino III and Barack Obama during U.S.-ASEAN Summit 2.17.16.jpg|thumb|left|President Aquino conversing with U.S. President Barack Obama during the U.S.-ASEAN Summit in Rancho Mirage, California, February 17, 2016]] President Aquino attended the special United States-ASEAN Summit hosted by U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] from February 15 to 16 at the [[Sunnylands]] estate in [[Rancho Mirage, California]], joining the other leaders of the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] (ASEAN).<ref>{{cite news|title=PNoy to attend special ASEAN-US leaders' summit next week|url=http://news.pia.gov.ph/article/view/3001455184899/pnoy-to-attend-special-asean-us-leaders-summit-next-week|accessdate=February 12, 2016|work=[[Philippine Information Agency]]|publisher=[[Presidential Communications Group (Philippines)|Philippine Presidential Communications Group]]|date=February 12, 2016}}</ref> According to a statement released by the [[White House]], the summit aims to strengthen cooperation on "political, security and economic issues" between the United States and the [[Member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations|ASEAN member states]] under the United States-ASEAN strategic partnership signed in November 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=US sets February date for ASEAN summit in California|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/us-sets-february-date-for/2388634.html|accessdate=December 31, 2015|work=[[Channel NewsAsia]]|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|publisher=[[MediaCorp]]|date=December 31, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Obama will host the US-ASEAN Summit in Rancho Mirage, California on February 15–16.|url=http://sputniknews.com/us/20151230/1032521741/obama-hold-us-asean-rancho-mirage.html|accessdate=February 12, 2016|agency=[[Sputnik (news agency)|Sputnik]]|date=December 30, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Statement by the Press Secretary on the U.S.-ASEAN Summit|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2015/12/30/statement-press-secretary-us-asean-summit|publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]]|accessdate=February 12, 2016|date=December 30, 2015}}</ref> Aquino is also expected to raise the issue on the [[territorial disputes in the South China Sea]] which the Philippines is a claimant along with Brunei, Malaysia, and Vietnam.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aquino to raise South China Sea row at ASEAN-US summit|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/122078-aquino-south-china-sea-dispute-asean-us-summit|accessdate=February 12, 2016|work=[[Rappler]]|date=February 11, 2016}}</ref> On February 16, after participating in the summit, Aquino visited Los Angeles to address the [[World Affairs Councils of America|Los Angeles World Affairs Council]], which according to the council is regarding the "new defense agreement between Manila and [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]], security in East Asia, and the future for economic growth in the Philippines and its neighbors in Southeast Asia," at the [[InterContinental]] hotel in [[Century City, Los Angeles|Century City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Aquino to speak before Los Angeles World Affairs Council in California|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/breaking_news/aquino-to-speak-before-los-angeles-world-affairs-council-in-california/|accessdate=February 12, 2016|work=[[The Manila Times]]|agency=[[Philippines News Agency]]|date=February 12, 2016}}</ref> On February 17, President Aquino received an honorary [[Doctor of Humane Letters]] degree from the [[Loyola Marymount University]] "in recognition of his dedication to his country, his integrity, and his embodiment of a Jesuit education." He also met with Los Angeles-based investors and the Filipino-American community in Los Angeles, before departing for Manila.<ref>{{cite news|title=President Aquino to receive honorary Doctorate from Loyola Marymount University in California|url=http://www.canadianinquirer.net/2016/02/12/president-aquino-to-receive-honorary-doctorate-from-loyola-marymount-university-in-california/|accessdate=February 12, 2016|work=Philippine Canadian Inquirer|agency=[[Philippines News Agency]]|date=February 12, 2016}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} [[File:Immortal Regiment in Moscow (2018-05-09) 13.jpg|thumb|Netanyahu and [[Vladimir Putin]] with a war veteran in Moscow. May 9, 2018]] The following is a '''list of international prime ministerial trips''' made by [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] as [[Prime Minister of Israel]]. ==First term (1996–1999)== {{expand list|date=July 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Country!!Dates!!Purpose!!Notes |- |{{flag|United States}} |July 10, 1996 |Address to the US Congress |{{cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?73411-1/israel-prime-minister-speech|title=Israel Prime Minister Speech|work=[[C-Span]]|date=July 10, 1996|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} |- |{{flag|China}} |August 24, 1997 |rowspan="4"|Working visit |{{cite web|url=http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/CHINA-amp-JAPAN-ISRAELI-PRIME-MINISTER-BENJAMIN-NETANYAHU-VISIT/cd1d9a92bd6f15efee9e4d72d04f2ec8?query=MIDDLE+EAST¤t=2&orderBy=Relevance&hits=2&referrer=search&search=%2Fsearch%3Fquery%3DMIDDLE%2520EAST%26allFilters%3DProduction%2520facilities%3ASubject%2CIBA%3ASource&allFilters=Production+facilities%3ASubject%2CIBA%3ASource&productType=IncludedProducts&page=1&b=4f2ec8|title= CHINA & JAPAN: ISRAELI PRIME MINISTER BENJAMIN NETANYAHU VISIT|work=[[The Associated Press]] archive|date=August 24, 1997|accessdate=July 24, 2018}} |- |{{flag|Japan}} |August 24–27, 1997 | |- |{{flag|South Korea}} |August 28, 1997 |{{cite web|url=http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/SOUTH-KOREA-NETANYAHU-PROPOSES-JOINT-SECURITY-SCHEME/f336454c28c36bc7c7218ca8aa00045a?current=12&hits=11&query=MIDDLE%20EAST&orderBy=Relevance&referrer=search&search=%2fsearch%3fquery%3dMIDDLE%2520EAST%26allFilters%3dIBA%3aSource%2cTechnology%3aSubject&page=1&b=00045a&allFilters=IBA%3aSource%2cTechnology%3aSubject|title=SOUTH KOREA: NETANYAHU PROPOSES JOINT SECURITY SCHEME|date=August 28, 1997|accessdate=July 24, 2018}} |- |{{flag|Azerbaijan}} |August 29, 1997 |First visit by an Israeli PM to Azerbaijan{{cite news|url=https://fas.org/irp/news/1997/970829-il.htm|title=Netanyahu Meets with President of Azerbaijan in Baku|work=Israel Line|date=August 29, 1997|accessdate=July 19, 2018}} |} ==Second term (2009–2013)== {{expand list|date=July 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Country!!Dates!!Purpose!!Notes |- |{{flag|United Kingdom}} |August 25–26, 2009 |Discussions |{{cite web |title=Press Conference by PM Netanyahu and UK PM Brown |url=http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/PressRoom/2009/Pages/Press_Conference_PM_Netanyahu_and_UK_PM_Brown_25-Aug-2009.aspx |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=25 Aug 2009}}{{cite web |title=Joint statement by PM Netanyahu and US Envoy Mitchell |url=http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/PressRoom/2009/Pages/Joint_statement_PM_Netanyahu_US_Envoy_Mitchell_26-Aug-2009.aspx |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=26 Aug 2009}} |- |{{flag|Germany}} |August 26–27, 2009 |[[State visit]] |{{cite web |title=Press conference of PM Netanyahu and German Chancellor Merkel |url=http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/PressRoom/2009/Pages/Press_conference_PM_Netanyahu_German_Chancellor_Merkel_27-Aug-2009.aspx |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=27 Aug 2009}} |- |{{flag|United States}} |March 24, 2010 |Discussions |{{cite news |title=Netanyahu, Obama meet at White House - CNN.com |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/POLITICS/03/23/us.israel/index.html |work=CNN |date=24 March 2010 |language=en}} |- |{{flag|United States}} |May 24, 2011 |Address to the US Congress |{{cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?299666-1/israeli-prime-minister-netanyahu-address-joint-meeting-congresss|title=Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu Address to Joint Meeting of Congress|publisher=[[C-Span]]|date=May 24, 2011|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} |- |{{flag|Canada}} |March 2–4, 2012 |[[State visit]] |{{cite web|url=https://nationalpost.com/news/canada/why-israels-prime-minister-is-coming-to-canada-before-heading-to-the-u-s|title=Why Israel’s Prime Minister is coming to Canada before meeting Obama|author=Boesveld, Sarah|work=[[National Post]]|date=March 1, 2012|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} |- |{{flag|United States}} |March 5–?, 2012 |Discussions |{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/06/world/middleeast/obama-cites-window-for-diplomacy-on-iran-bomb.html|title=Obama Presses Netanyahu to Resist Strikes on Iran|author=Landler, Mike|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 5, 2012|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} |- |{{flag|United Nations}} |September 26–27?, 2012 |[[General debate of the sixty-seventh session of the United Nations General Assembly|UNGA address]] |{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/28/world/middleeast/netanyahu-warns-that-iran-bombmaking-ability-is-nearer.html|title=Nod to Obama by Netanyahu in Warning to Iran on Bomb|authors=Gladstone, Rick; Sanger, David E.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 27, 2012|accessdate=July 20, 2018}} |- |{{flag|Czech Republic}} |December 5, 2012 |Discussions |{{cite web |title=Statement by PM Netanyahu at meeting with Czech PM Nečas |url=http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/PressRoom/2012/Pages/PM_Netanyahu_meets_Czech_PM_Necas_5-Dec-2012.aspx |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=5 December 2012}} |- |{{flag|Germany}} |December 5–6, 2012 |[[State visit]] |{{cite web |title=PM Netanyahu meets with German Chancellor Merkel |url=http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/PressRoom/2012/Pages/PM_Netanyahu_meets_German_Chancellor_Merkel_6-Dec-2012.aspx |publisher=Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs |date=6 December 2012}} |- |} ==Third term (2013–2015)== {{expand list|date=July 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Country!!Dates!!Purpose!!Notes |- |{{flag|China}} |May 5–10, 2013 |[[State visit]] |{{cite Meeting With Putin Not Set Up Yet |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/netanyahu-heads-to-paris-conference-meeting-with-putin-not-set-up-yet-1.6637380 |work=Haaretz |date=10 November 2018 page.title: List of longest mountain chains on Earth

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2409:4055:583:F64B:6FBC:D471:6754:3915|2409:4055:583:F64B:6FBC:D471:6754:3915]] ([[User talk:2409:4055:583:F64B:6FBC:D471:6754:3915|talk]]) to last version by Shyamsunder
revision.text:
[[File:Cuernos del Paine from Lake Pehoé.jpg|350px|thumb|right|The [[Andes]] range consist of hundreds of [[mountain]] [[Summit|peaks]]. ]] The '''world's longest above-water mountain range''' is the [[Andes]],[http://www.blueplanetbiomes.org/andes.htm ''Andes Mountains'' by Alan W./Knapp Gregory. 1999] Retrieve 2002Windows to Universe [http://www.windows2universe.org/geography/andes.html ''The Andes Mountains'' by: Julia Genyuk.] Retrieve 17 November 2008 about {{convert|7,000|km|abbr=on}} long. The range stretches from north to south through seven countries in [[South America]], along the west coast of the continent: [[Venezuela]], [[Colombia]], [[Ecuador]], [[Peru]], [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], and [[Argentina]]. [[Aconcagua]] is the highest peak, at about {{convert|6,962|m|abbr=on}}. This list does not include submarine mountain ranges. If submarine mountains are included, the longest is the global [[mid-ocean ridge]] system which extends for about {{convert|65,000|km|abbr=on}}. ==Formation== Mountain chains are typically formed by the process of [[plate tectonics]]. [[Tectonic plate]]s slide very slowly over the [[Earth]]'s [[mantle (geology)|mantle]], a lower place of rock that is heated from the Earth's interior. Several huge sections of the earth’s crust are impelled by heat currents in the mantle, producing tremendous forces that can buckle the material at the edges of the plates to form [[mountain]]s. Usually one plate is forced underneath the other, and the lower plate is slowly absorbed by the mantle. Where the two plates pass one another, heated [[Rock (geology)|rock]] from the mantle can burst through the [[Crust (geology)|crust]] to form [[volcano]]es. The movement of the plates against one another can also cause [[earthquake]]s. ==List== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- style="background:#ececec;" !Rank !Range !Continent !Country !Coordinates !Approx. length !Approx. width !Max. elevation !Highest point |- |1 |[[Andes]] |[[South America]] |{{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Argentina]]

page.title: North Pacific Exploring and Surveying Expedition

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "A United States scientific and exploring project from 1853 to 1856." ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|A United States scientific and exploring project from 1853 to 1856.}} [[Image:John Rodgers.jpg|thumb|150px|[[John Rodgers (naval officer, Civil War)|John Rodgers]]]] The '''North Pacific Exploring and Surveying Expedition''', also known as the '''Rodgers-Ringgold Expedition''' was a United States scientific and exploring project from 1853 to 1856.
Commander [[Cadwalader Ringgold]] (1802–1867) led the expedition until he was relieved of command in [[Hong Kong]] by a commission convened by Commodore [[Matthew C. Perry|Matthew Perry]]. Lt. [[John Rodgers (naval officer, Civil War)|John Rodgers]] (1812–1882) then commanded the expedition until its conclusion.
==The expedition under Ringgold== [[Image:Commodore Cadwalader Ringgold.jpg|thumb|left|upright |[[Cadwalader Ringgold]] ]] Ringgold sailed on [[USS Porpoise (1836)|USS ''Porpoise'']], a ship he had commanded during the [[U.S. Exploring Expedition]] years before. [[USS John Hancock (1850)|USS ''John Hancock'']], commanded by Lt. [[John Rodgers (naval officer, Civil War)|John Rodgers]] and three other vessels including [[USS Vincennes (1826)|USS ''Vincennes'']] would be the other vessels in the expedition.
''Porpoise'' joined the squadron at Hampton Roads, and with it, stood out to sea 11 June 1853. After stopping at [[Funchal]], [[Madeira Islands]]; [[Porto Praya]]; and [[Simonstown]], [[False Bay]]; the expedition arrived [[Jakarta|Batavia]], [[Java (island)|Java]], 12 December and in [[China]] in March 1854.
Five months were devoted to surveying the waters surrounding the large islands off the coast of Southeast Asia. Early in May 1854, ''John Hancock'', with Rodgers commanding, departed for [[Hong Kong]], where she arrived 24 May. The squadron operated from that port as its base throughout the summer, surveying nearby coasts, islands and rivers. At this time [[China]] was plagued by rebellion and [[pirate]]s endangering foreigners and threatening their property. The American ships helped protect American citizens and interests. While steaming up the [[Pearl River (China)|Canton River]], two armed boats from ''John Hancock'' were fired upon by rebel batteries, which ''Hancock'''s cannon promptly silenced.
==From Hong Kong to the United States== [[Image:USS Porpoise (1836).jpg|thumb|right|[[USS Porpoise (1836)|USS Porpoise]]]]
In July 1854, Ringgold became sick with malaria and was sent home, according to at least one source.<ref name=fraser>[https://www.questia.com/PM.qst;jsessionid=FvPM4s2QZ207lH0LK4PgT4g5LlKhs6gCQ1xQ1GqhpZC1lPQMQKQR!15464514?a=o&d=5002380544 Questia.com] Questia Online Library Web site copy of: Houston, Alan Fraser, "Cadwalader Ringgold, U. S. Navy" an article in ''California History'' magazine, Volume 79, Issue 4, Winter 2000, page 208, Web site accessed October 19, 2006, Footnote 11</ref> However, Nathaniel Philbrick, in his book "Sea of Glory" about the U.S. Exploring Expedition, writes that in the later expedition Ringgold "began to act strangely" once in China, keeping his ships in port "ceaselessly repairing his vessels". Commodore Perry, on his own expedition, sailed in and convened an official panel which relieved Ringgold from command of the expedition and sent him home. Philbrick quotes Perry as declaring Ringgold "insane."<ref>Philbrick, Nathaniel, ''Sea of Glory: America's voyage of discovery, The U.S. Exploring Expedition, 1838-1842'' (Viking: 2003), {{ISBN|0-670-03231-X}} pages 351,-352</ref> [[John Rodgers (naval officer, Civil War)|John Rodgers]] was given full command of the expedition and completed it.
The squadron headed north along the coast as far as the [[Bering Sea]], surveying as it went. The squadron at that time also explored islands well off the coast of Asia, including the [[Bonins]], the [[Mariana Islands|Ladrones]], and the [[Marianas]]. ''Porpoise'' parted company with the other vessels 21 September 1854 between [[Taiwan|Formosa]] and China, and was never heard from again. It is supposed that she foundered in a heavy typhoon which occurred a few days after her separation from the squadron.
At the Bering sea, the expedition turned south along the western coast of North America. In March 1856, the expedition arrived at [[Puget Sound]] to help suppress Indian uprisings which threatened to wipe out white settlements and Army outposts established in the early 1850s.
==Results of the expedition== Besides greatly increasing knowledge of the western and northern Pacific, stimulating commerce, and easing navigation in previously unknown seas, the expedition has been credited with helping to establish friendly relations between the United States and several nations of East Asia.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |title= The North Pacific surveying and exploring expedition or, My last cruise, where we went and what we saw, being an account of visits to the Malay and Loo-Choo Islands, the coasts of China, Formosa, Japan, Kamtschatka, Siberia, and the mouth of the Amoor River |author= Alexander Wylly Habersham |publisher= J.B. Lippincott and Company |location= Philadelphia |year= 1857 |url= https://archive.org/details/northpacificsurv00haberich }}
{{DANFS}}
[[Category:Exploration]] [[Category:Oceanography]] [[Category:History of science and technology in the United States]] [[Category:History of the Pacific Ocean]] [[Category:United States Navy in the 19th century]]
[[Category:Military expeditions of the United States]] [[Category:1853 in the United States]] [[Category:Asian expeditions]] [[Category:Pacific expeditions]] [[Category:Expeditions from the United States]] [[Category:1853 in Oceania]] [[Category:1853 in Asia]]

{{Globalize|date=December 2010}} {| class="infobox bordered" style="width: 17em; text-align: left; font-size: 95%;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | '''Notice to Mariners''' |- | colspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | [[Image:Notice-to-mariners-thumb.jpg|175px]]
The front cover of a Notice to Mariners. |- ! Purpose: | Provide corrections to navigational publications and nautical charts. |- ! Publication Frequency: | Weekly |- ! Published by: | [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] |- ! Available Online: | Yes [http://msi.nga.mil/NGAPortal/MSI.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=msi_portal_page_61] |- |} A '''notice to mariners''' (NTMWeb site uses abbreviation NTM) advises mariners of important matters affecting navigational safety, including new [[Hydrography|hydrographic information]], changes in [[channel (geography)|channel]]s and aids to [[navigation]], and other important data. Over 60 countries which produce nautical charts also produce a notice to mariners. About one third of these are weekly, another third are bi-monthly or monthly, and the rest irregularly issued according to need. For example, the [[United Kingdom Hydrographic Office]] issues weekly updates. ==United States== The U.S. ''Notice to Mariners'' is made available weekly by the [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] (NGA), prepared jointly with the [[National Ocean Service]] (NOS) and the [[U.S. Coast Guard]]. The information in the ''Notice to Mariners'' is formatted to simplify the correction of [[nautical chart|paper charts]], ''[[List of Lights]]'', ''[[Light List]]s'', ''[[United States Coast Pilots]]'', and other publications produced by NGA, NOS, and the U.S. Coast Guard. Information for the ''Notice to Mariners'' is contributed by: the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency (Department of Defense) for waters outside the territorial limits of the United States; National Ocean Service ([[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]], [[Department of Commerce]]), which is charged with surveying and charting the coasts and harbors of the United States and its territories; the U.S. Coast Guard ([[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]]) which is responsible for the safety of life at sea and the establishment and operation of aids to navigation; and the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Army Corps of Engineers]] ([[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]]), which is charged with the improvement of rivers and harbors of the United States. In addition, important contributions are made by foreign hydrographic offices and cooperating observers of all nationalities. The Notice consists of a page of Hydrograms listing important items in the Notice, a chart correction section organized by ascending chart number, a product catalog corrections section, a publications correction section, a summary of broadcast navigation warnings, and a page of additional miscellaneous information. It is the responsibility of users to decide which of their charts and publications require correction. Mariners are requested to cooperate in the correction of charts and publications by reporting all discrepancies between published information and conditions actually observed and by recommending appropriate improvements. A reporting form is provided in the back of each ''Notice to Mariners''. Issue No. 1 of each year contains important information on a variety of subjects which supplements information not usually found on charts and in navigational publications. This information is published as Special Notice to Mariners Paragraphs. Additional items considered of interest to the mariner are also included in this Notice. Much of the data in the U.S. ''Notice to Mariners'' is obtained from foreign notices. ==Canada== In Canada, the Canadian Coast Guard (CCG) [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/ Notice to Mariners] publication informs mariners of important navigational safety matters affecting Canadian Waters. This electronic publication is published on a monthly basis and can be downloaded from the [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/go.php?doc=eng/services/notmar/index Notices to Mariners (NOTMAR) Web site]. The information in the Notice to Mariners is formatted to simplify the correction of paper charts and navigational publications. The [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/ NOTMAR.gc.ca] site is a free 24/7 service providing mariners with up-to-date safety advisories. It provides mariners with a quick and easy to use interface to access Notices to Mariners information. This system also generates [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/search/mycharts-eng.php?czozMDoibnRtPXN0ZXBfb25lc3RhcnQmYWNjZXB0cHJpdj0xIjs= weekly and monthly notification mailers], for its registered users. These on-line mail services provides the [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/subscribe/ monthly Notices to Mariners publications] as well as the weekly(section II - chart corrections) notices that advise the mariner of the notices that have been issued against their chart selections. These mail services simplify the process for registered clients to update their publications and charts as required under the Canada Shipping Act. The NOTMAR web site also includes the [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/go.php?doc=eng/services/notmar/numindex historical Chart corrections] and [http://www.notmar.gc.ca/go.php?doc=eng/services/notmar/sec4index historical Sailing Direction corrections]; as well, it provides access to downloadable Chart Patches, contains links to CHS’s Chart Number 1, instructions for applying Notices to mariners to manually update their paper charts, and other useful information. ==Summary of Corrections== A close companion to the ''Notice to Mariners'' is the '''[http://msi.nga.mil/MSISiteContent/StaticFiles/SOCDownloadPage.htm Summary of Corrections]'''. The ''Summary'' is published in five volumes. Each volume covers a major portion of the earth including several chart regions and many subregions. Volume 5 also includes special charts and publications corrected by the ''Notice to Mariners''. Since the Summaries contain cumulative corrections, any chart, regardless of its print date, can be corrected with the proper volume of the Summary and all subsequent ''Notice to Mariners''. ==See also== *[[Notice to Airmen]] — [[aeronautical]] equivalent *[[American Practical Navigator]] *[[Buoy]] *[[Coast Pilots]] *[[Light List]] *[[List of Lights]] *[[Local Notice to Mariners]] *[[Sailing Directions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== The text of this article originated from sections 418 and 419 of The [[American Practical Navigator]], a document produced by the government of the [[United States|United States of America]]. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061016164246/http://www.irbs.com/bowditch/pdf/chapt04.pdf Chapter 4: Nautical Publications] - from the online edition of [[Nathaniel Bowditch]]'s ''American Practical Navigator'' * [http://msi.nga.mil/NGAPortal/MSI.portal?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=msi_portal_page_61 Notice to Mariners Online] {{Navigation publications}} {{Works about sailing}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Notice To Mariners}} [[Category:Navigation]] [[Category:Hydrography]] [[Category:Sailing books]]

revision.text:
[[File:Exval.jpeg|thumb|right|Poor passage planning and unchecked deviation from the plan can lead to [[Ship grounding|groundings]], [[Ship collision|collisions]] and [[oil spill]]s.]]'''Passage planning''' or '''voyage planning''' is a procedure to develop a complete description of a vessel's voyage from start to finish. The plan includes leaving the dock and harbor area, the ''en route'' portion of a voyage, approaching the destination, and [[Mooring (watercraft)|mooring]], the industry term for this is 'berth to berth'. According to international law, a vessel's [[captain (nautical)|captain]] is legally responsible for passage planning,<ref name="reg34">{{cite web | title = Regulation 34 – Safe Navigation | url = https://mcanet.mcga.gov.uk/public/c4/solas/solas_v/Regulations/regulation34.htm | work = IMO RESOLUTION A.893(21) adopted on 25 November 1999 | accessdate=March 26, 2007}}</ref> The duty of passage planning is usually delegated to the ship's navigation officer, typically the [[second mate|second officer]] on [[merchant ship]]s.<ref name="annex24">{{cite web | title = ANNEX 24 – MCA Guidance Notes for Voyage Planning | url = https://mcanet.mcga.gov.uk/public/c4/solas/solas_v/Annexes/Annex24.htm | work = IMO RESOLUTION A.893(21) adopted on 25 November 1999 | accessdate=March 26, 2007}}</ref>
Studies show that [[human error]] is a factor in 80 percent of navigational accidents and that in many cases the human making the error had access to information that could have prevented the accident.<ref name="annex24"/> The practice of voyage planning has evolved from penciling lines on [[nautical chart]]s to a process of [[risk management]].<ref name="annex24"/>
==Planning stages== [[File:Cruising sailor navigating.jpg|thumb|Monitoring progress and comparing it to the plan are key to passage planning.]] Passage planning consists of four stages: appraisal, planning, execution, and monitoring.<ref name="annex24"/> These stages are specified in ''[[International Maritime Organization]] Resolution A.893(21), Guidelines For Voyage Planning,''<ref name="annex25-1">International Maritime Organization, Section 1 of ''Guidelines for Voyage Planning'', 1999.</ref> which are, in turn, reflected in the local laws of IMO signatory countries.<ref>For example, in [[33 CFR|Title 33 of the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations]]</ref> The ''Guidelines'' specify fifty elements of passage planning, some of which are only applicable in certain situations.<ref name="bow367"/>
The ''Guidelines'' specify three key items to consider in the practice of voyage planning:
*having and using a voyage plan is "of essential importance for safety of life at sea, safety and efficiency of navigation and protection of the marine environment,"<ref name="annex25-1"/> * voyage planning is necessary for all types of vessels on all types of voyages,<ref name="annex25-1"/> and * the plan's scope should be based on all information available, should be "berth to berth," including when [[harbour pilot|under pilotage]], and the plan includes the execution and the monitoring of progress.<ref name="annex25-1"/>
Voyage planning starts with the appraisal stage. Before each voyage begins, the navigator should develop a detailed [[mental model]] of how the entire voyage will proceed.<ref name="bow367">Bowditch 2002, p. 367.</ref> The appraisal stage consists of gathering and contemplating all information relevant to the voyage. Much of this appraisal is done by consulting [[nautical chart]]s, [[nautical publications]] and performing a number of technical tasks such as weather forecasting, prediction of tides and currents, and checks of local regulations and warnings.<ref name="annex25-2">International Maritime Organization, Section 2 of ''Guidelines for Voyage Planning'', 1999.</ref>
Nautical publications are a valuable guide to local conditions and regulations, but they must be updated and actually read to be of any use.<ref name="chap4">{{cite web |title = Chapter 4, Nautical Publications |url = http://www.irbs.com/bowditch/ |work = [[American Practical Navigator]] |accessdate = March 26, 2007 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070624193729/http://www.irbs.com/bowditch/ |archivedate = June 24, 2007 |df = }}</ref> These publications could include [[Sailing Directions]] and [[Coast Pilots]] or similar texts produced by other authorities.<ref name="annex25-2"/>
The next stage of the process is known as the planning stage. Once information is gathered and considered, the navigator can begin the process of actually laying out the voyage. The process involves projecting various future events including landfalls, narrow passages, and course changes expected during the voyage.<ref name="bow367"/> This mental model becomes the standard by which the navigator measures progress toward the goal of a safe and efficient voyage, and it is manifested in a passage plan.<ref name="bow367"/>
A good passage plan will include a track line laid out upon the best-scale charts available.<ref name="bow267">Bowditch 2002, p.214.</ref> This track is judged with respect to at least nine separate criteria given in the ''Guidelines'' including under-keel clearance, safe speed, air draft, the use of routing and reporting services (TSS and VTS), and the availability of contingencies in case of emergency.<ref name="annex25-3">International Maritime Organization, Section 3 of ''Guidelines for Voyage Planning'', 1999.</ref>
[[File:Navigation system on a merchant ship.jpg|right|thumb|Modern navigators often enter passage plans on [[ECDIS|electronic systems]]]]The navigator will draw and redraw the [[Course (navigation)|track line]] until it is safe, efficient, and in line with all applicable laws and regulations.<ref name="bow367"/> When the track is finished, it is becoming common practice to also enter it into electronic navigation tools such as an [[Electronic Chart Display and Information System]], a [[chartplotter]], an [[Automatic radar plotting aid|ARPA]] system, or a [[GPS]] unit.<ref name="bow224-225">Bowditch 2002, pp 224–225.</ref>
When working in a team environment, the passage plan should be communicated to the navigation team in a pre-voyage conference in order to ensure that all members of the team share the same mental model of the entire trip.<ref name="bow367"/>
The third stage of passage planning is the execution stage. The IMO was careful to include execution as part of the process of passage planning. This underscores the fact that the ''Guidelines'' list a number of tasks that are to executed during the course of the voyage. It also reiterates the captain's responsibility to treat the plan as a "living document" and to review or change it in case of any special circumstances that should arise.<ref name="annex25-4">International Maritime Organization, Section 4 of ''Guidelines for Voyage Planning'', 1999.</ref>
The fourth and final stage of voyage planning is the monitoring stage. Once the voyage has begun the progress of the vessel along its planned route must be monitored. This requires that the ship's position be determined, using standard methods including [[dead reckoning]], [[celestial navigation]], [[Maritime pilot|pilotage]], and [[electronic navigation]].
According to the ''Guidelines,'' the passage plan should always be available to the [[deck officer|officer on watch]] on the bridge. The ''Guidelines'' also specify that deviations from the plan should be clearly recorded and be consistent with other provisions of the ''Guidelines.''<ref name="annex25-5">International Maritime Organization, Section 5 of ''Guidelines for Voyage Planning'', 1999.</ref>
==Computer aids== In modern times, computer software can greatly simplify the passage planning process and ensure that nothing important is overlooked.<ref name="bow367"/> Passage planning software may include functions such as waypoint management, distance calculators, tide and tidal current predictors, celestial navigational calculators, consumables estimators for fuel, oil, water, and stores, and other useful applications.<ref name="bow367"/>
==Notes== {{Portal|Nautical}} {{Commons|Navigation}}

The permanent adjustments of [[theodolite]]s are made to establish fixed relationship between the instrument's fundamental lines. The fundamental lines or axis of a [[theodolite|transit theodolite]] include the following:- * [[Vertical axis]] * Axis of plate levels * Axis of [[telescope]] * Line of collimation * [[Horizontal axis]] * Axis of altitude bubble and the vernier should read zero. These adjustments once made last for a long time. These are important for accuracy of observations taken from the instrument. The permanent adjustments in case of transit theodolite are:- * '''Horizontal axis adjustment'''. The horizontal axis must be [[perpendicular]] to the vertical axis. * '''Vertical circle index adjustment'''. The vertical circle must read [[zero]] when the line of [[collimation]] is horizontal. * '''Adjustment of altitude level'''. The axis of altitude level must be [[parallel (geometry)|parallel]] to the line of collimation. * '''Collimation adjustment'''. The line of collimation or line of sight should coincide with axis of the telescope.<ref>Surveying by Dr. B.C Punmia and Dr Ashok Kumar Jain</ref> The line of sight should also be perpendicular to the horizontal axis at its intersection with the vertical axis . Also, the [[optical axis]] , the axis of the objective slide, and the [[Sightline|line of sight]] should coincide. * '''Adjustment of horizontal plate levels'''. The axis of plate levels must be perpendicular to the vertical axis.<ref>surveying volume 1 by Prof. C.L Kochher, page no. 340 and 341.</ref>
==See also== * [[Temporary adjustments of theodolite]] * [[Ranging rod]]s * [[Tape (surveying)]]

[[File:Typus Orbis Terrarum drawn by Abraham Ortelius.jpg|thumb|right|Terra Australis is the large continent on the bottom of this 1570 map.]] [[File:Peary_Sledge_Party_and_Flags_at_the_Pole.jpg|thumb|right|[[Robert Peary]] and sledge party with flags at North Pole. April 1909. Peary has been claimed to be the first person to reach the North Pole.]] [[File:At the South Pole, December 1911.jpg|thumb|right|Roald Amundsen, [[Helmer Hanssen]], [[Sverre Hassel]] and [[Oscar Wisting]] (l–r) at "Polheim", the tent was upright at the South Pole on 16 December 1911. The top flag is the [[Flag of Norway]]; the bottom is marked "''Fram''". Photograph by [[Olav Bjaaland]].]] [[File:The Three Polar Stars, 1913 (8889621500).jpg|thumb|right|The "Three Polar Stars" – [[Roald Amundsen]] {South Pole}, [[Ernest Shackleton]](crossing of Antarctica), and Robert Peary {North Pole}– together in January 1913]]
'''Polar exploration''' is the process of [[exploration]] of the [[polar regions]] of the [[Earth]] - the [[Arctic region]] and [[Antarctica]] - particularly with the goal of reaching the [[North Pole]] and [[South Pole]], respectively. Historically, this was accomplished by explorers making often arduous travels on foot or by sled in these regions, known as a '''polar expedition'''. More recently, exploration has been accomplished with technology, particularly with [[satellite imagery]].
From 600 BC to 300 BC [[Greek philosophy|Greek Philosophers]] theorized that the planet was a [[Spherical Earth]] with [[North Pole|North]] and [[South Pole|South]] [[Polar region]]s. By 150 [[Anno Domini|AD]] [[Ptolemy]] published [[Geographia (Ptolemy)|Geographia]], which notes a hypothetical [[Terra Australis|Terra Australis Incognita]]. However, due to harsh weather conditions, the poles themselves would not be reached for centuries after that. When they finally were reached, the achievement was realized only a few years apart.
There are two claims, both disputed, about who was the first person to reach the [[geographic North Pole]]. [[Frederick Cook]], accompanied by two [[Inuit]] men, Ahwelah and Etukishook claimed to have reached the Pole on April 21, 1908, although this claim is generally doubted. On April 6, 1909, [[Robert Peary]] claimed to be the first person in recorded history to reach the North Pole,<ref name="arcticchronology">{{Cite web|url=http://www.quarkexpeditions.com/arctic/exploration.shtml|title=ARCTIC EXPLORATION - CHRONOLOGY|accessdate=2006-10-19|publisher=Quark Expeditions|year=2004 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060911074922/http://www.quarkexpeditions.com/arctic/exploration.shtml |archivedate = 2006-09-11}}</ref> accompanied by his employee [[Matthew Henson]] and four Inuit men Ootah, [[Seegloo]], Egingway, and Ooqueah (although whether he actually reached the Pole is doubted by some).<ref name="columbia">{{Cite web|url=https://www.questia.com/library/encyclopedia/arctic_the.jsp|title=ARCTIC, THE|accessdate=2006-10-19|publisher=[[Columbia University Press]]|year=2004|work=Columbia Encyclopedia, Sixth Edition}}</ref><ref name="caencyclo">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=J1ARTJ0005796|title=North Pole|accessdate=2006-10-20|publisher=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|year=2006}}</ref>
Norwegian explorer [[Roald Amundsen]] had planned to reach the [[North Pole]] by means of an extended drift in an icebound ship. He obtained the use of [[Fridtjof Nansen]]'s polar exploration ship ''[[Fram]]'', and undertook extensive fundraising. Preparations for this expedition were disrupted when Cook and Peary each claimed to have reached the North Pole. Amundsen then changed his plan and began to prepare for a conquest of the [[geographic South Pole]]; uncertain of the extent to which the public and his backers would support him, he kept this revised objective secret. When he set out in June 1910, he led even his crew to believe they were embarking on an Arctic drift, and revealed their true Antarctic destination only when ''Fram'' was leaving their last port of call, Madeira.
[[Amundsen's South Pole expedition]], with Amundsen and four others, arrived at the pole on 14 December 1911,<ref>Some sources give the date as 15 December. Since the western and eastern hemispheres are conjoined at the South Pole, both dates can be considered as correct, though Amundsen gives 14 December, both in his first telegraphed report on arrival in Hobart, and in his fuller account, ''The South Pole''. Huntford, ''The Last Place on Earth'' (1985), p. 511.</ref> five weeks ahead of a British party led by [[Robert Falcon Scott]] as part of the [[Terra Nova Expedition]]. Amundsen and his team returned safely to their base, and later learned that Scott and his four companions had died on their return journey.
